self care.title: Self Care during Pregnancy and Afterbirth
body: Rest: Get enough rest, especially when your baby is sleeping.
Eat well: Eat a variety of healthy foods, including whole grains, fruits, vegetables, and protein. Stay hydrated, especially if you're breastfeeding
Exercise: Build physical activity into your day, but avoid strenuous activity. You can start with daily walks with your baby.
Accept help: Ask for and accept help from friends and family. They can help take care of the baby or the house
Take it easy: Be patient with your body as it recovers and heals. Take things at your own pace
Make time for yourself: Do some of the things you enjoyed doing before baby.
Connect with others: Join a mommy support group or connect with other new parents at early years programs, parenting classes, and fitness classes
Follow your doctor's orders: Don't skip your follow-up appointments.

Manage afterpains: Afterpains are common during breastfeeding and feel like menstrual cramps. A healthcare professional might suggest a pain reliever like acetaminophen (Tylenol) or ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB).
Improve mental health: Exercise can help improve your mental health.

body.vaccine: Vit A, Measles for sero-exposed babies

Infant Nutrition.title: Infant Nutrition
body: Infant nutrition is important for a child's survival, growth, and development. Here are some tips for infant nutrition
Breastfeeding:Ideally, infants should be put to breast within an hour of birth and breastfed exclusively for the first six months. Breast milk contains all the necessary vitamins and minerals
Solid foods: Introduce solid foods at around six months of age. Start with pureed, mashed, or semi-solid foods. By eight months, most infants can eat finger foods.
Food variety: Offer a variety of foods from different food groups, including fruits, vegetables, grains, yogurt, cheese, and meat or other proteins.
Food consistency: Gradually increase the consistency and variety of foods as your infant gets older
Food preparation: Prepare foods safely
Food allergies: Introduce one new food at a time to identify any foods that cause allergies. Allergic reactions include diarrhea, vomiting, or a rash.
Vitamin D: Provide your baby with a vitamin D supplement soon after birth.
Drinks: Avoid drinks with low nutrient value, such as tea, coffee, and sugary soft drinks. Limit the amount of juice offered

Early childhood health.title: Positive Parenting Tips
body: As a parent, to promote early childhood health, you should focus on providing your child with proper nutrition, regular medical checkups, a safe environment, responsive caregiving through interaction and play, and actively fostering their development through talking, singing, and reading to them regularly; essentially creating a nurturing environment that supports their physical, emotional, and cognitive growth from birth onwards.Key actions to take

Nutrition: Breastfeed your baby exclusively for the first six months, then introduce solid foods appropriately. Offer a balanced diet with plenty of fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and lean protein.Limit sugary drinks and unhealthy snacks.
Healthcare: Follow recommended immunization schedules. Attend all scheduled well-baby checkups and screenings. Address any health concerns promptly with your pediatrician.
Safe environment: Baby-proof your home to prevent accidents. Supervise your child closely during playtime. Use car seats and booster seats properly when traveling.
Responsive caregiving: Talk, sing, and read to your child often. Make eye contact and respond to their cues. Provide cuddles and comfort when needed. Engage in age-appropriate play activities.

Early learning stimulation: Provide toys and activities that promote sensory development. Encourage exploration and curiosity. Read books with your child and discuss the pictures. Teach basic skills like colors, shapes, and numbers.
Mental health support: Be patient and understanding with your child's emotions. Model positive coping mechanisms. Seek professional help if you notice any concerning behaviors.
